Resolved Question Show me another » When icebergs melt? What would happen? Now if I placed a huge iceberg into the sea the waterlevel would rise, but what happens when the iceberg melts? would the level stay at the same level as it was with the iceberg ? or would it increase ? Is the amount of water the same frozen or would it increase as it melts? Is the volume the same? or does the part of the iceberg sticking out of the water add volume? I think that wether part of the iceberg is out or not it still has the same mass and so therefore when it melts should not add to the level ? 4 years ago Report Abuse by zee_prim... Member since: 14 April 2006 Total points: 22,991 (Level 6) Add Contact Block
Best Answer - Chosen by Asker Nope, melting icebergs don't contribute to sea level rise, only icecaps on dry land, like Greenland, Antarctica and glaciers. If those all melted, sea level would rise about 80 metres. Try this experiment. Fill a glass with ice cubes. Carefully fill it to the brim with water and mop up any spilled water. You should see that when the ice has all melted, no water has overflowed, even though they projected above the rim. 4 years ago Report Abuse
